text: [Music]
If I was a young artist, I'd probably go
and live in Germany because I think that
Germany is the motor of Europe and it's
the
intellectual center of the art world.
And Berlin is very similar to what New
York
was. And New York may be possibly at the
end of its
uh burning life as an art center. You
know, New York may be moving to what to
be what Paris was in the
60s. It's still it's still a
headquarters in a certain sense, a
showing place.
But uh
creativity creativity I might move to
uh yeah I might go to Berlin where you
can get cheap places. And it's very
important when you're a young artist to
have friends because you have to keep
each other warm. You have to hold each
other, learn from each other, support
each other, make a society and keep each
other warm. And that's how you can get
through.
Well, I found the whole
um figurative art movement fascinating.
I thought it was a a wonderful defense
of painting. And I don't particularly
make a distinction between abstraction
and figuration in terms of what I like,
what I'm attracted to. And I'm very
attracted to the Leipkig school of
painters Neo Ral for example I find very
very nice and
um and many others there are many
others and I I thought that was a very
interesting way of
uh
renovating an interesting painting. And
what seems to happen or what has
happened so far is that there's a a
strong sense of
figuration. I don't know if this is an o
oversimplification and it it well any
any generalization is oversimplification
but in times of richness
wealth figurative
art what's sometimes known as pop art
and all its derivations painterly pop
art and so on which the young German
painters were interested in tends to be
in the foreground and very dominant
because it's popular and more people get
involved. But as art
withers to its
trunk, it gets
harder and then abstraction seems to
make a comeback. And this is certainly
what happened. If you look back at the
90s where there's a lot of
abstraction, the 80s where there was a
lot of figuration and that was a epoch
of copious wealth. The 70s was abstract,
the 60s was full up with pop art. So
this seems to happen and now we might be
looking at a lot of abstract
painting. Well, I think the next
generation of of of uh artists,
painters, artists will be more
um concerned
with a kind of regeneration of spiritual
value, a reflective art as opposed to a
populist, bombastic
obvious art. I think there will be more
um integrity in art
because art and politics do hold hands.
They do walk down the avenue
together. And I think we're going to see
that and we've got that now in the
United States. We've got to move
significantly to social order, social
awareness, social caring, a sense of
responsibility, repairing the the
extremely
tarnished, wantingly tarnished image of
America, outside
America, and a sense of global
responsibility, the sense that we're all
in a family together, which is what
um John F. Kennedy talked about. But we
all breathe the same air. It's a famous
remark and I think we will return to
that
and the artists will be concerned
with a more
reflective vision.
